awd_titl_txt: SCC-RCN: Developing an Informational Infrastructure for Building Smart Regional Foodsheds
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to build a transdisciplinary research coordination network (RCN) bringing together researchers and community stakeholders to build a general informatics framework for understanding and optimizing the food system. While food production currently generates enough calories to feed the world's population, disparities and failures in the food system lead to negative health effects within the U.S. and across the world. Mitigating these food and nutrition failures can help to meet the goal of creating smart, connected, and healthy sustainable communities. A key goal of this project is to allow community members (including those from diverse populations) to inform the research network of their needs. It will do so through work on three integrated objectives: (1) improve understanding of the interrelated components and actors in the food system; (2) developing prototype information technologies to capture these relationships and to enable information sharing and analysis; and (3) organizing and coordinating food system stakeholders in two key agricultural regions of the United States to determine ways this information can be used to strengthen their regional food systems (referred to hereafter as "foodsheds") and those of other communities. The primary focus of this project is on foodsheds in the Sacramento, California and Columbus, Ohio regions, with subsequent efforts to expand participation in the network to other regions.

Research undertaken through this project will contribute to a addressing the problem of  lack of information flow among researchers, policymakers, and diverse food system stakeholders. Developing novel methods for bringing together diverse data streams (climatic, environmental, genetic/genomic, product composition, production, importation, processing, distribution, marketing, food policy, health and healthcare) will allow researchers to better characterize the food system, enabling communities to address food system failures, inequities and other challenges. These activities will be coordinated by a steering committee of researchers and community members with expertise in computer science, economics, medicine, food science, sustainable agriculture, data analytics, engineering, public policy, and public health.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The goals of the SCC-RCN: "Developing an Informational Infrastructure for Building Smart Regional Foodsheds" are to address food system failures, inequities and other challenges by characterizing the food system within two specific regions: a 6-county Sacramento, California foodshed, and a 7-county Columbus, Ohio foodshed. The aims of the RCN are to: (1) better understand the interrelated components and actors in the food system; (2) develop information technologies to capture these relationships and enable information sharing; and (3) bring food system stakeholders together in two key agricultural regions of the U.S. to determine ways this information can be used to strengthen these regional food systems and provide a blueprint for responding to informatics needs of other communities.

The "Smart Foodsheds" RCN has successfully filled its role as a research coordination network in two dimensions: one by developing a semantically-structured technical base/knowledge graph for capturing food system information--now linked with burgeoning AI problem-solving tools through the integration of Smart Foodsheds as one of three use-inspired science research areas within the NSF funded ICICLE AI institute (icicle.ai). The second is through building a committed and growing network of transdisciplinary researchers and community stakeholders that leverage and expand the informatics tools and initial food system use cases developed through the RCN project to address real-world challenges in our two target foodsheds and beyond.

Intellectual Merit

Recent attempts to catalog the challenges facing the food system highlight a specific problem: a lack of information flow among researchers, policymakers, and diverse food system stakeholders. Developing novel methods for bringing together diverse data streams (climatic, environmental, genetic/genomic, product composition, production, importation, processing, distribution, marketing, food policy, health and healthcare) is essential to allow researchers to better characterize the food system, enabling communities to address food system failures, inequities and other challenges. Outputs from this work that are supporting this needed informational access and convergence across disciplines include: 

  • Continued development of ontologies and knowledge graphs, 

  • Exploratory visualizations of the knowledge graph for a food system, 

  • Entries into dataverse in the areas of food production, mobility patterns, and county-to-county food flows,

  • Linked spatially-referenced databases describing Ohio food supply chains,

  • Initial food flow analysis for Ohio dairy and meat producers and processors,

  • Continued collaboration on methods to link spatial information and knowledge graphs,

  • Contributions to new USDA project exploring establishment of regional supply chains for meat production and processing in California,

  • Organization of conversations among networks of organizations from public health, health care, and social service organizations around sharing and linking data,

  • Establishment of Data Commons as a model for sharing data at OSU campus between multiple groups working on food insecurity and food access,

  • Expanded use of "people-projects-organizations-datasets" (PPOD) ontology and data structure in food systems applications and through introduction to another network of researchers focusing on reproductive health interested in learning how PPOD can help them organize information around their research and community engagement network,

  • Contributions to a framework for policy changes for meat production and processing in California.

  • As a capstone to the RCN, a special topical collection has been published in the open access peer-reviewed journal Sustainability, including a comprehensive review article introducing the term "food systems informatics" and six research articles based on food systems use cases. TP Tomich and C Hoy, eds. 2023. Special Collection on Smart and Connected Food Systems.  
    https://www.mdpi.com/journal/sustainability/special_issues/smart_food_system

Broader Impact

The RCN is helping create smart, connected, equitable, healthy, and sustainable foodsheds by providing timely information needed for mitigating community food and nutrition failures and inequalities and enabling connection of a broad suite of issues and data sources relevant to improving the function of food and agricultural systems. The project has built detailed knowledge graphs about food systems actors and activities operating in the two project foodsheds (Sacramento region and Columbus region) and structured data infrastructure for replication and use in problem solving across a variety of food systems and challenges. As part of this process, hundreds of stakeholder partners from well over 50 partnering academic and community organizations have been engaged in co-design of applied use cases--leading to solutions and strategies that are rooted in the needs of the communities involved. Moreover, this provides a scalable framework for analyzing and solving food system challenges and using better data to create "Smart Foodsheds". An expanding series of linked research and implementation projects have been built from the RCN network and technical platform, representing additional research funding of more than $56 Million for continued work addressing food system challenges found in meat supply chains in CA and nationwide with related links to climate change mitigation, meat and dairy in OH, and public health, food access, and nutrition in OH and CA, to name a few. Smart Foodsheds research has grown into a thriving tool for understanding and optimizing US food system performance and working to solve ongoing challenges.
